# Stovetop Pesto Pasta

## Introduction
Stovetop Pesto Pasta is a classic Italian dish that combines al dente pasta with a vibrant and flavorful pesto sauce. This dish is known for its simplicity and versatility, making it a favorite among pasta lovers. The pesto sauce, made with fresh basil, garlic, pine nuts, Parmesan cheese, and olive oil, adds a burst of herbaceous and nutty flavors to the pasta.

## Ingredients
- 8 ounces (225g) of pasta (such as spaghetti, linguine, or penne)
- 2 cups (50g) fresh basil leaves, packed
- 3 cloves of garlic
- 1/4 cup (30g) pine nuts
- 1/2 cup (50g) grated Parmesan cheese
- 1/2 cup (120ml) extra-virgin olive oil
- Salt and pepper to taste

## Equipment
- Large pot for cooking pasta
- Colander for draining pasta
- Food processor or blender
- Wooden spoon or spatula

## Preparation Time
- 10 minutes

## Cooking Time
- 10-12 minutes

## Steps
1. Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Add the pasta and cook according to package instructions until al dente. Drain the pasta in a colander and set aside.
2. In the meantime, prepare the pesto sauce. In a food processor or blender, combine the basil leaves, garlic, pine nuts, and Parmesan cheese. Pulse until the ingredients are finely chopped.
3. With the food processor or blender running, slowly drizzle in the olive oil until the mixture is smooth and well combined. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
4. Transfer the cooked pasta back to the pot and add the pesto sauce. Stir well to coat the pasta evenly with the sauce.
5. Place the pot over low heat and gently warm the pasta for a minute or two, stirring occasionally. Be careful not to overheat the pesto sauce as it may lose its vibrant green color.
6. Remove the pot from the heat and serve the Stovetop Pesto Pasta immediately.

## Serving Suggestions
- Serve the Stovetop Pesto Pasta as a main course with a side of garlic bread and a fresh green salad.
- Garnish with additional grated Parmesan cheese and a sprinkle of freshly chopped basil for added flavor and presentation.

## Variations
- For a creamier pesto sauce, add a tablespoon or two of heavy cream or Greek yogurt to the sauce before tossing it with the pasta.
- Add cooked chicken, shrimp, or roasted vegetables to the pasta for a heartier meal.

## Tips and Tricks
- Toast the pine nuts in a dry skillet over medium heat for a few minutes until they become fragrant and lightly golden. This step enhances their nutty flavor.
- If you prefer a smoother sauce, blend the pesto for a longer time until it reaches your desired consistency.
- Reserve a small amount of pasta cooking water before draining. If the pasta seems dry after adding the pesto sauce, you can add a splash of the reserved pasta water to loosen it up.

## Nutritional Information
- The nutritional information for Stovetop Pesto Pasta may vary depending on the type of pasta used and the amount of pesto sauce added. Here is a general approximation per serving (based on 4 servings):
  - Calories: 500
  - Fat: 35g
  - Carbohydrates: 40g
  - Protein: 12g

## Storage and Leftovers
- Stovetop Pesto Pasta is best enjoyed fresh. Leftovers can be stored in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 2 days. To reheat, gently warm the pasta in a pan over low heat, adding a splash of water or olive oil to prevent it from drying out.

## Frequently Asked Questions
- Q: Can I use a different type of pasta for this recipe?
  - A: Yes, feel free to use any type of pasta you prefer or have on hand. Just adjust the cooking time accordingly.
- Q: Can I make the pesto sauce in advance?
  - A: Yes, you can make the pesto sauce in advance and store it in the refrigerator for up to 3 days. Make sure to cover it with a thin layer of olive oil to prevent oxidation.
- Q: Can I freeze the pesto sauce?
  - A: Yes, you can freeze the pesto sauce in an airtight container or ice cube trays for up to 3 months. Thaw it in the refrigerator before using.
